results.title: A Letter to Amy
results.creator_credit: Morton Schindel, Weston Woods Studios and Cynthia Freitag
results.brief_description: Tells the story of Peter, a young African American boy, who is planning his birthday party. Shows him pondering over the invitation letter and then anxiously awaiting the party day to see if she comes. Concludes with Amy arriving very late, thus making the party a happy one.

results.title: A Letter for Marie
results.brief_description: South African born Marie has been diagnosed with Alzheimer’s disease. Her husband, Tom, speaks of their 33-years together and of the good times still to come. Created as part of ‘Memory’s Voice: Capturing Stories of Courage’ in association with Vic Health and the Alzheimer’s Association.

results.title: A Lesson to us all
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Face Australia”.
Outwardly, Japan is an economic and industrial giant, whose growth from the ashes of WWII into a powerful trading nation is a remarkable success story. This film looks at both sides of the Japanese story, contrasting the nation’s material wealth and manufacturing efficiency with the divisions created by changed social conditions, the tragic effects of uncontrolled pollution and pessimistic outlooks of concerned citizens.

results.title: A Lesson for teacher (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
In 1976 Dr Neville Bennett of Lancaster University published his research report evaluating the success and failure of various systems used in British primary schools. This was the first major attempt to analyse scientifically just how much children learn in establishments ranging from the most progressive, open-plan schools, to the most traditional. The publication of the report was an important educational event, and it will give rise to much questioning about the direction of current trends in British education. The report revealed that in one year pupils taught by formal methods can be as much as five months in advance educationally of those taught by the free style

In 1976 Dr Neville Bennett of Lancaster University published his research report evaluating the success and failure of various systems used in British primary schools. This was the first major attempt to analyse scientifically just how much children learn in establishments ranging from the most progressive, open-plan schools, to the most traditional. The publication of the report was an important educational event, and it will give rise to much questioning about the direction of current trends in British education. The report revealed that in one year pupils taught by formal methods can be as much as five months in advance educationally of those taught by the free style.

results.title: A Lecture on man
results.creator_credit: Richard Williams Films and Richard Williams
results.brief_description: Using live action clips, still photography and various animation techniques, Richard Williams illustrates a lecture given by Christopher Logue on the human situation. It is a satirical look at humans, their aspirations, and habits. The twin evils of patriotism and nationalism are exposed. (Awards: Mannheim; Annecy)
results.description: Using live action clips, still photography and various animation techniques, Richard Williams illustrates a lecture given by Christopher Logue on the human situation. It is a satirical look at humans, their aspirations, and habits. The twin evils of patriotism and nationalism are exposed. (Awards: Mannheim; Annecy)

results.title: A Lecture on anatomy
results.creator_credit: Geo Tapparelli, Lux Film and Glauco Pellegrini
results.brief_description: This Italian art film is an essay on the theory that “the shape of the human body is determined by necessity and regulated by a principle which gives the greatest result for the least effort - the best of engineers could not invent a more perfect and economical structure. Humans could not be different from what they are because they could not be simpler”. Commentary in English.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Geo Tapparelli, Lux Film and Glauco Pellegrini
